q: What are the symptoms of bloating?
a: Symptoms of bloating include feeling full or bigger than usual, tummy pain or discomfort, rumbling or noises in the stomach, and increased flatulence.

q: What are some common causes of bloating?
a: Common causes of bloating include having a lot of gas in your gut, certain food and drinks, swallowing air while eating, constipation, food intolerance, coeliac disease, and irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). Bloating can also occur around the time of your period.

q: How can I reduce bloating?
a: To reduce bloating, you can try exercising regularly, chewing with your mouth closed, drinking plenty of water, eating high-fiber foods if constipated, having smaller, frequent meals, and massaging your stomach from right to left. Avoid drinking lots of fizzy drinks, alcohol, caffeine, foods that cause gas, and large meals late at night.

q: What can a pharmacist help with regarding bloating?
a: You can ask a pharmacist about laxatives for constipation and medicines like Buscopan to help ease bloating.

q: When should I see a GP for bloating?
a: You should see a GP if you've been feeling bloated for 3 weeks or more, feel bloated regularly (more than 12 times a month), have tried changing your diet but still feel bloated, have a swelling or lump in your tummy, experience bloating along with being sick, diarrhoea, constipation, weight loss, or blood in your stool, or find it difficult to move or do daily activities due to bloating.

q: What should I do if I have severe stomach pain?
a: If you have severe stomach pain that came on suddenly, hurts when touched, vomiting blood, black or bloody stool, inability to urinate, defecate, or fart, difficulty breathing, or chest pain, call 999 or go to A&E.

q: Is treatment always needed for bloating?
a: Treatment for bloating is often not needed. However, if necessary, it will depend on the cause. A GP may refer you to an NHS dietitian or a specialist for tests to determine the underlying cause of your bloating.
